raw_text:
Rusedski angry over supplements
 
 Greg Rusedski has criticised the governing body of men's tennis for not releasing contamination-free supplements in time for the new season.
 
 Rusedski said: "I tried to order some but didn't receive any and I haven't got any yet. "You would think they would have been available in December as it can take two months for the body to respond. "This event comes in the hottest period of the year, so you would hope the stuff would be available for it." The British number two escaped a possible ban last year when he persuaded a tribunal that a positive doping test was the result of contaminated ATP supplements. In response, the ATP struck a deal with pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline to provide contamination-free drinks and nutritional bars for the men's tour.
 
 David Higdon, Vice President of the ATP, admitted: "I agree with Greg. "I would have loved to have had these things available as soon as possible but it's a lot of work to make sure they have gone through rigorous testing. "The reality is though that the first two weeks of the tour are spread far and wide and part of the distribution agreement we had with GSK has an education component. "We weren't going to just drop these products out there without having a talk with the players about understanding how to use them.
 
 "The first chance we will get to do that is at the players meeting on the Saturday before the Australian Open." And Rusedski, who takes on Roger Federer at the Qatar Open later on Wednesday, conceded that the imminent changes will be beneficial. "The good thing is that there is now a 100% guarantee, so hopefully all this will never happen again," said Rusedski. "Hopefully after the Australian Open we won't have to discuss this any more."
llama3.2:1b: Greg Rusedski criticized the ATP governing body for not releasing contaminated supplements in time for the new season. The British number two had ordered them but didn't receive any and hadn't received theirs yet. David Higdon, Vice President of the ATP, acknowledged that availability was delayed due to rigorous testing. However, the distribution agreement with pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline included an education component requiring players to understand how to use the products. Rusedski agreed that this would be beneficial and expressed hope that they wouldn't have to discuss the issue again after the Australian Open.
llama3.2:3b: Greg Rusedski criticized the ATP for not releasing contamination-free supplements in time for the new season, which could affect player performance during the hottest period of the year. The ATP struck a deal with GlaxoSmithKline to provide clean products but distribution began after the first two weeks of the tour due to an education component. Rusedski welcomed the 100% guarantee that such issues won't happen again.
gemma2:2b: Greg Rusedski criticized the ATP for delayed release of clean supplements ahead of the new tennis season. He experienced a similar issue last year with contaminated supplements leading to a potential ban, but an agreement with GlaxoSmithKline now provides contamination-free products for players. The ATP acknowledges the delay and stresses the need for education about using these supplements before distribution, promising this will happen at the Australian Open player's meeting.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Rusedski's tennis supplement concerns have led to controversy and conflict between the ATP and Men's Tennis Federation (ATP). Although ATP has promised to release contamination-free supplements earlier, it still hasn't received them in time for the new season. Rusedski expressed his frustration at this delay, stating that he hadn't ordered any supplements and doesn't have any yet. He also emphasized the importance of these products due to their potential benefits in a high-stress tennis environment.

David Higdon, ATP's vice president, acknowledged Rusedski's point about availability but admitted it would be difficult to provide them immediately since they require rigorous testing beforehand. The ATP has agreed that supplements will be made available at the players' meeting before the Australian Open on the day of the match, which could allow for some discussions regarding their use.

Rusedski's comments indicate that there are ongoing issues in the sport regarding doping and nutrition, with ATP still struggling to release certain products promptly.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Greg Rusedski criticized ATP for not releasing contamination-free supplements in time for the new season. Despite being banned due to contaminated ATP supplements last year, Rusedski believed the issue would be resolved with a deal signed with GlaxoSmithKline. He also acknowledged that the first two weeks of the tour's distribution is spread wide and requires player education before availability. The upcoming Australian Open meeting will provide an opportunity for this information.
qwen2.5:3b: Greg Rusedski criticizes the ATP for not providing contamination-free supplements in time for the new season. Despite his efforts to order them by December, he received none and still has not obtained any. Last year, Rusedski avoided a ban due to contaminated ATP supplements; now, GlaxoSmithKline provides such products through an agreement with the ATP. David Higdon acknowledges that providing these supplements promptly is challenging, as it includes educating players about their proper use. Rusedski sees this as beneficial and hopes future discussions on these matters will be unnecessary after the Australian Open.
opencoder:1.5b: Rusedski's criticism of the governing body for not releasing contaminated supplements is a clear case of anger and uncertainty. Greg Rusedski has made an uncalled-for statement, urging opposition in tennis-related matters, claiming they can expect contaminated supplies. However, Rusedski was right that they couldn't wait until after the men's tennis tournament when it comes to season-long supplies. Regrettably, he didn't react appropriately and left a negative impression on the public about the future of men's tennis.
smollm:1.7b:
Summarizing text concisely requires identifying the main ideas and key points in the original text. In this case, the main idea is that Rusedski has criticized the governing body of men's tennis for not releasing contamination-free supplements in time for the new season. The supporting details include:

1. Rusedski said: "I tried to order some but didn't receive any and I haven't got any yet."
2. He complained about the lack of availability, saying: "You would think they would have been available in December as it can take two months for the body to respond."
3. The governing body's response was inadequate, leading Rusedski to believe that contamination-free supplements were not being released on time.
4. The ATP struck a deal with GSK to provide contaminated supplements, which Rusedski agreed with.
5. He acknowledged: "I agree with Greg. I would have loved to have had these things available as soon as possible but it's a lot of work to make sure they have gone through rigorous testing."
6. The first chance we will get to do that is at the players meeting on the Saturday before the Australian Open, which Rusedski believes will be beneficial.
7. The good thing is that there is now a 100% guarantee, so hopefully all this will never happen again.

The summary captures the main idea of the text and provides key details to support it.

tinydolphin:1.1b:
Acknowledging the concerns and frustrations of Greg Rusedski, the ATP's Vice President has admitted that contaminated supplements were not readily available before the start of the new tennis season. The British player took a different approach in securing ATP supplements, persuading the governing body to provide free contamination-free options for players at the players' meeting on December 23.

Higdon, ATP's Vice President, admits that they faced several challenges in ensuring the safety of their players and staff during this period. The first two weeks of the tour are spread across various countries and it's a lot of work to make sure all items have gone through rigorous testing.

Rusedski's main concern is that the ATP didn't inform its players about these supplementary issues in time for the start of the new season. The ATP is set to relocate from New York to Doha for the Australian Open, which gives them the opportunity to discuss these concerns with their players beforehand. Rusedski acknowledges that the ATP may have missed out on an opportunity to avoid further problems.

In response, Higdon admits that contaminated supplements were not readily available in December last year when Greg Rusedski was suspicious of their efficacy. GSK and the ATP have reached a deal to provide free contamination-free options at the players' meeting on December 23.

The ATP's decision to provide free ATP supplements at the players' meeting is an attempt to ensure fairness for all players in the new season, but it could also be seen as a way of avoiding further problems and ensuring that future events can proceed without incident.
